In a Shake-Up, Kodak Replaces Consumer Chief Kodak replaced the head of its ailing consumer division, David P. Biehn, left, part of an accelerating effort to cut costs and reconstruct its photography business.

Kodak said Mr. Biehn would be replaced on Oct. 13 by Robert Keegan, who now runs the company's professional division. The announcement comes a week after Kodak said it would dismiss 200 senior and middle managers, or about one-fifth of the managers worldwide, and warned that earnings for this year could be off by as much as 25 percent.

Raytheon-Hughes Deal Is Approved Raytheon won approval from Federal antitrust officials to buy the military business of Hughes Electronics, but the companies agreed to take several steps intended to maintain competition.
Orders Gain for Third Month A strong increase in demand for electronic components contributed to a 1.3 percent rise in factory orders in August, the third straight monthly advance.
Federal Reserve policy makers expressed concern about labor and health costs at their Aug. 19 meeting, even as they left interest rates unchanged, minutes showed.

Stocks and Bonds Advance Most major indexes rose to records in a modest stock market rally, led by small-cap and technology shares. The notable exception was the Dow Jones industrial average, but it still managed a 12.03-point gain to close at 8,027.53, its second consecutive finish above 8,000 since Aug. 20.

Treasury securities rallied further on optimism that September unemployment data released today would provide further evidence of benign inflation. The 30-year bond yield settled at 6.30 percent, down from 6.32 and near its low for the year.

Anheuser Tactics Draw Scrutiny The Justice Department is investigating whether Anheuser-Busch has been using its enormous muscle to squeeze smaller competitors like microbreweries out of the beer market.
Business Data Services Being Sold Knight-Ridder is selling its on-line business information service, including its best-known brands, Dialog and Datastar, to M.A.I.D. of Britain for $420 million.
Hypertension Drug Is Approved Sanofi, the French drug maker, and Bristol- Myers Squibb have received approval from the Food and Drug Administration to market Irbesartan, an anti-hypertension drug.

Clinton Acts on Imports of Produce President Clinton said he would ask Congress to empower regulators to ban imports of fruit and vegetables from countries that do not meet American food safety standards, acting after outbreaks of disease linked to the increasing global trade in produce.

A Cool Reception Mr. Clinton also met with the chiefs of the Big Three auto makers to tout his trade policies, but received instead an earful of complaints about the Administration's interest in limiting emissions of gases that may contribute to global warming.

Iraq Tension Lifts Oil Prices Crude oil prices rose to their highest level in four months because of tensions between Iraq and United Nations weapons inspectors and concern over an impending strike by oil workers in Colombia.

CNN Won't Run Global Warming Ads CNN told a coalition of industrial companies that it would no longer broadcast the group's advertisements criticizing the Clinton Administration's negotiating stance in talks on controlling global warming.
